OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Made cancer spot on omentum more visible; made the omentum tissue look more shear and less like gray stripes
Added the omentum and moved the cancer spot and the tumor size inset box to the omentum, per reviewer.
Removed the cancer spot that is on the right fallopian tube near the top of the uterus
Removed the cancer spots that arenâ€™t in the ovaries and fallopian tubes, and removed the cancer that is growing out of the ovaries onto adjacent tissue.

REVISED IMAGE per FIGO update: Removed "ovarian cancer" from title; added the lymph node group that is shown on the lower, left side of the Stage IIIC illustration and labeled the Lymph nodes; on the right side of the image, reduced size of the cancer spot that has the pull-out for Tumor size a tiny bit so that it is actually in the peritoneum layer (but does not go through it).
Reduced the size of the tumor on the peritoneum.

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Drawing of stage IIIB shows cancer inside both ovaries that has spread to the omentum. The cancer in the omentum is 2 centimeters or smaller. An inset shows 2 centimeters is about the size of a peanut. Also shown are the small intestine, colon, fallopian tubes, uterus, bladder, and lymph nodes behind the peritoneum.

Drawing of stage IIIB shows cancer inside both ovaries that has spread to the omentum. The cancer in the omentum is 2 centimeters or smaller. An inset shows 2 centimeters is about the size of a peanut. Also shown are the small intestine, colon, fallopian tubes, uterus, bladder, and lymph nodes behind the peritoneum.

Captions.MediaCaption: In stage IIIB, cancer is found in one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and has spread to the omentum, and the cancer in the omentum is 2 centimeters or smaller. Cancer may have spread to lymph nodes behind the peritoneum.

In stage IIIB, cancer is found in one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and has spread to the omentum, and the cancer in the omentum is 2 centimeters or smaller. Cancer may have spread to lymph nodes behind the peritoneum.

MediaContent.Comment: 2016-01-26: Revised content & caption approved by OCC; added HP content & caption.
